title: When will UK families benefit? Energy giants blasted over failure to pass on wholesale cut
text:
When will UK families benefit? Energy giants blasted over failure to pass on wholesale cut When will UK families benefit? Energy giants blasted over failure to pass on wholesale cut AS Britain prepares for the coldest winter in 50 years, energy providers are once again under fire for rip-off bills. PUBLISHED: 00:17, Tue, Sep 22, 2015 | UPDATED: 10:16, Tue, Sep 22, 2015 GETTY Wholesale energy costs are falling 
Since January 2014 wholesale gas and electricity prices have plummeted by as much as 40 per cent. Over the same household energy bills, however, have fallen by a measly 10 per cent. Just one of the Britain's biggest suppliers, British Gas, has announced a price cut ahead of this winter - despite wholesale costs dropping by almost 20 per cent this year alone. Critics have said it's time that others followed suit. Capital Economics CPI Energy Prices show how customers' energy bills are lagging behind wholesale drops 
Stephen Murray, energy expert at comparison site MoneySuperMarket, said: “Suppliers might argue that the nominal reductions they made earlier in the year were at the right level however, wholesale prices have continued to fall meaning further cuts to household bills are now due. "Increased wholesale costs are reflected speedily by suppliers, it’s time they adopt the same approach for falling prices also."Not one of the top ten cheapest energy deals on the market is currently offered by one of the biggest six suppliers, who hold a whopping 90 per cent of the market share between them. MoneySuperMarket, 21.09.2015 Top Ten Energy Tariffs 
As a result, experts have urged households to vote with their feet and move to a better deal. Seven out of ten homes are estimated to be able to move to a cheaper deal, found the Competitions and Market Authority (CMA) in the summer when it published provisional findings after a year-long investigation of the market. Mr Murray added: "The best thing homeowners can do to make savings to their bills is to switch energy supplier. "The biggest proportion of the nation’s energy customers, around 70 per cent, are sitting on the most expensive standard tariffs with many of them never switching to a cheaper deal. "For those who fall in to this category our advice is to compare tariffs on offer and make a switch that can bring in savings of around £200."Express.co.uk asked the other Big Five providers when they will follow British Gas and cut prices for their customers as a result of falling wholesale costs.
